displayed_text: Patient: None of that. Doctor: And how just overall energy level since we stopped the study have you had? Noticed worsening, better, same? Patient: Well, uh, I could say, I don’t have as much energy as I had when I was on testosterone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right? So that, that has diminished. Uh, uh, let’s see, I, I’m just trying to think through the process because I’m still- Doctor: I mean, you’re still up? You’re still kind of doing the things you want to do? You’re not like-? Patient: Right. Right. Right. Right. Right. Yeah. Because we was on vacation for twelve days. So that, that threw off everything with me. Doctor: Since I saw you last? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Where’d you guys go? Patient: South Africa. Doctor: Oh, that’s right. How was that? Patient: Oh, mind blowing.

Patient: Or bend it backwards. The right side ain’t bothering me. It’s just that one that, well, the one that the screw came loose. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, any numbness or tingling? Patient: What? In my neck? Doctor: Your arms, your legs. Patient: No. And the only other thing that now and then is my shoulder blade from the day, from the first day that I was operated on. I was telling the nurse and everything while I was still in the hospital it felt like I had three shoulder blades at times. In fact, I told you that. Doctor: Is that getting worse? Or is it just present? Patient: No. It’s about the same. Doctor: Okay. How’s your heart been? Patient: All right. I woke up this morning. I’m not being smart, but (laughs) Doctor: Okay. But not- no chest pain? Patient: Oh, no, no chest pains. No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your hot flashes?

Family Member 1: In the last two weeks. But we knew it was all for your spine, been that for two years. Doctor: Great. Sorry about that. I just needed to check. Huh, huh, so we also, you know, checked your molecular stuff and there wasn’t anything that jumped out, huh, that says that we have something that we could add a treatment to. You crying? What’s that about? Patient: Dying. Dying. Doctor: Do you feel like you’re dying or just that’s-? Patient: Well you know it’s going to happen. Doctor: Okay. Huh, you have questions, or just-? Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: But if something's obviously seen on an additional scan, you know, we have clinical studies that we could think about. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we have one study where folks you know less than three spots. And as long as one is in bone, we radiate pinpoint radiation, the spots that we see- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -and half the people get of medicine that goes in their bloodstream that goes to cancer in the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so that would be something that you know, based on sort of, if we really think T12 is real or T3 is real, that could be something that we would send you off to the radiation doctors to have them talk about that trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then we get the PET scan and it actually says, you know, you've got 123 plus 456, you know, that we think most of this is real, we can step back and watch a little bit longer until either declares itself a little bit more. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or just say hey, it's there. And then we have a couple studies where the current standard for the guy who shows up with multiple spots is to go on hormones for life. Patient: Right.

Patient: B___. Family Member: B___. Doctor: And you got it the same day you saw me or you got, you went over there earlier today or-? Family Member: He got it done here today. They made an appointment here today. Doctor: Okay. Huh, but normally you go to B___? Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. I had the blood test done this morning. Is that what we were reading off for the PSA this morning? Doctor: Yep. Yeah. You might give me a little bit longer than two weeks since you don’t go to Medicare, huh, until, huh, Friday. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yeah. March first it kicks in. I’ve got the card on me if you need it. Family Member: I’ve also got that, our insurance too. Doctor: Okay. So I just emailed the pharmacist to let them know what we’re thinking, huh, to get you started, that’s you’ve switched to Medicare, and that they might end up looking next week. Huh, so hopefully, in the next week or two we’ll know where you are.

Patient: This would be two. Doctor: Yeah. We’ll do three more of this um because again there’s a little interruption, there’s radiation, you know so we’ll just do four total Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Did you make a comment once that um that chemo doesn’t go up the skull or up to the brain or something like that? Doctor: It doesn’t typically penetrate to go to brain tissue, but it will penetrate to skull because that’s part of the bone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll target the area even though you had it radiated. It still would be going around Patient: Okay. Doctor: the neck. It just doesn’t go into the brain. Patient: I don’t want that to come back. Doctor: Yes, we don’t want it to come back either.

Family Member: Try something else. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Makes sense? Patient: Okay. Family Member: We stand, we stand in agreement with you. Doctor: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse. Family Member: Right. That’s good. Doctor: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else. Family Member: That’s a blessing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled.

Patient: Well, they’re giving me a combination. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: Anything is possible. (Laughter) Patient: It got better. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: Nice to see you. Nice to see you. Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again.

Family Member: I know. I tolerate this guy all by myself. Doctor: I know. All by yourself. Patient: Come on in and have a seat there. I’ve got friends waiting. Doctor: How come I’m over here? Patient: You can’t get these things together. Do you need me to get together or what? (Laughter) Patient: No. Doctor: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Is that on purpose for filming? Family Member: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink. Family Member: Oh.

Patient: Oh, I’m I’m just got the pain medicine going on. Just tired ‘cause I’ve been sitting, I’ve went down there and then I’m sitting out there ‘cause it was you know busy so I’ve been sitting out there for… Doctor: Wow because your appointment was way before I’ve seen so many people so I thought you weren’t here. Patient: No I was over here at the lab. It was so packed over there. Doctor: Oh my gosh you’re kidding me. Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is the pain? (patient makes a noise) Patient: Yeah I took some ah I took my pain medicine… Doctor: Pain medicine. Patient: …before I got here. Doctor: Any better though since we started the chemo? Did you notice any difference in your appetite in your – how you’re feeling? I still feel kind of you know I just had heat flashes and all of that, but the pills that you gave me. Patient: They make me crazy. I was just… Doctor: I think, I think also I started you on the Prednisone remember for your along with the Chemo. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, we might need, if it’s something that frequent, we might need a port. Yeah, that’s a lot of beating up on you. You know, once every three weeks Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: you can get away with that and it’s like an hour but if you’re here twice a week it’s pretty painful. Patient: That’s possible that I don’t have to do that, right? Doctor: Well, you could always say no. You could say listen, I just want the chemo and I don’t want the vitamin C trial, just you know forget it and we would just do straight chemo. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse. Patient: So I’ll only be in Texas for now long? Doctor: One or two days. Patient: A couple of days? Doctor: Yeah. The scan takes literally two hours. Patient: Stay, stay in the hospital or is-? Doctor: No. I think they put you in a hotel.

Patient: I have great confidence in him as I do with you, but as you know. Doctor: Yep. No. I was picking his brain. Patient: You’ve got to ask twice. You know? Doctor: Every time. Every time. Patient: You know? Doctor: So he says hello and he’s happy you’re doing well. It’s just trying to a – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: get ahead of it. Patient: Um. Doctor: Do you feel any better from the radiation? Patient: My back is much better. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out. Doctor: The catheter is out now? Patient: Now it’s not; See that is the problem. Uh catheter was not out when it was supposed to be scheduled; the catheter but two days before it was supposed to be taken out I Doctor: Even with the catheter in? Patient: Well, the catheter was blocked. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. And I had peeing, but very little at the time. So they said it’s not doing it properly, so they put catheter back in. And they told me they shouldn’t have taken out. So the urologist told me; they should have flushed it and anyway, so.

Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we… Doctor: Yeah, Yes, that would have been. Yeah. Patient: Okay. I understand that now. Doctor: So, like back then would have been or if we get you stable and kind of quiet and good we could always redo it, Patient: We can still. Okay. Okay. Doctor: Right. So, it’s not off the table forever. It’s just at this moment it’s not. Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay. Doctor: Good. Family Member: I have one more question. Doctor: Yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Because he, when we last saw Dr. V____ in Vegas in July he was telling us there’s some research but it will be seven or eight months out. So that was July so it wouldn’t be until like next month about combining radium with the docetaxel. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so that’s already actually in trial. It is… Family Member: He thought it was better for the body.
